qas.question: What must a species do in order to be classified as a predator?

answers.text: direct impact on the prey population

qas.question: How would you describe a predator that primarily eats plants?
A predator must do what to the prey after it is killed?

answers.text: absorption of the prey's tissue through consumption

qas.question: A species that uses a host body to survive and reproduce is classified as a what?
How would you describe a diet of a species that eats primarily dead organic material?
Do detritivores have a direct impact on "donor" organisms?
What term is given to an organism that is being hunted?
What term is given to the biological interaction where a predator feeds upon prey?
What is the key characteristic of predation?

answers.text: predator's direct impact on the prey population

plausible_answers.text: a biological interaction where a predator (an organism that is hunting) feeds on its prey (the organism that is attacked)

qas.question: What is the definition of a host system?
What does prey eventually do to its predator's tissue in defense?
What is the feeding nature of some prey?
When does a carnivore know when it has a parasite?
What does a detrivore have a direct impact on while its trying to mature?

context: In an ecosystem, <a8_0>predation<a8_0/> is <b11_0>a biological interaction where a predator (an organism that is hunting) feeds on its <a7_0>prey<a7_0/> (the organism that is attacked)<b11_0/>. Predators may or may not kill their prey prior to feeding on them, but the act of predation often results in the death of the prey and the eventual <a2_0><b12_0>absorption<b12_0/> of the prey's tissue through consumption<a2_0/>. Thus predation is often, though not always, <b13_0>carnivory<b13_0/>. Other categories of consumption are <a1_0>herbivory<a1_0/> (eating parts of <a5_0>plants<a5_0/>), fungivory (eating parts of fungi), and <a4_0>detritivory<a4_0/> (the consumption of dead organic material (detritus)). All these consumption categories fall under the rubric of consumer-resource systems. It can often be difficult to separate various types of feeding behaviors. For example, some <a3_0>parasitic species<a3_0/> prey on a host organism and then lay their eggs on it for their offspring to feed on it while it continues to live in or on its decaying corpse <b14_0>after it has died<b14_0/>. The key characteristic of predation however is the <a10_0>predator's <a0_0>direct impact on <b15_0>the prey population<b15_0/><a10_0/><a0_0/>. On the other hand, detritivores simply eat <a9_0>dead organic material<a9_0/> arising from the decay of dead individuals and have <a6_0>no<a6_0/> direct impact on the "donor" organism(s).
